citation.article-title: Transfer of the type species of the genus Methanococcus to the genus Methanosarcina naming it Methanosarcina mazei (Barker 1936) comb. nov. et emend. and conservation of the genus Methanococcus (Approved List 1980) with Methanococcus vannielii (Approved List 1980) as the type species: Request for an Opinion.

p.s: Methanococcus (Me.tha.no.coc'cus. N.L. n. methanum methane; N.L. n. coccus spherical cell; N.L. masc. n. Methanococcus methane coccus)
Cells are fragile, regular to irregular cocci that are 0.5 to 5 μm in diameter and occur singly or in pairs.
Cells are highly motile (flagella may be inserted in clusters) and gram negative.
There is a single layer of protein subunits external to the plasma membrane.
Ether-linked polyisoprenoid (branched) chain lipids are the predominant lipid components.
Energy for growth is obtained by oxidation of H2 or formate with reduction of CO2 to CH4.
Cells contain coenzyme M and coenzyme F420, Carbohydrates, proteinaceous material, and organic compounds other than formate are not used as energy sources.
Yeast extract is stimulatory, and Se and W may be stimulatory for growth.
The optimal growth temperature is between 32 and 40°C; the optimal pH varies with species from pH 6.7 to 9.0.

The deoxyribonucleic acid base composition is 31 mol% guanine plus cytosine (determined for Methanococcus voltae DSM 153T and Methanococcus vannielii DSM 1224T), as determined by the buoyant density method.
The type species is Methanococcus vannielii Stadtman and Barker 1951, 269 (Approved Lists 1980).
